abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Uttar Pradesh State
            Roads Project for India were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the project document should ensure that: (i) project
            development objectives (PDOs) and monitoring indicators are
            few, measurable, and objective; and (ii) the project design
            incorporates a well-designed evaluation system for assessing
            the baselines and subsequently achievement of project
            outcomes. The agencies involved must ensure (using needed
            time and resources) that the necessary preparatory
            activities are indeed completed fully. Also, the period
            between the project preparation and beginning of the
            implementation should be minimized to avoid facing major
            changes in physical conditions. The Government's
            sustained ownership is extremely vital to undertake such
            large projects. This is the second State Roads Project
            (Kerela State Transport Project) implemented in recent years
            for which the envisaged scope had to be scaled down and also
            incurred substantial time, and cost overrun.
